description:
Corynebacterium senegalense is a species of gram-positive, aerobic, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacteria. It belongs to the genus Corynebacterium, which is a group of bacteria commonly found in the human microbiome and associated with various clinical conditions.

Corynebacterium senegalense was first isolated from the skin of healthy individuals in Senegal, West Africa, hence the species name "senegalense." It is a member of the Corynebacterium diphtheriae group, which includes other clinically relevant species within the genus.

The cells of Corynebacterium senegalense are typically rod-shaped and can form characteristic "palisade" arrangements or irregular clusters. They are typically catalase-positive and can be biochemically differentiated from other Corynebacterium species based on their ability to utilize certain carbon sources and their pattern of enzymatic activities.

While Corynebacterium senegalense is not considered a major human pathogen, it has been occasionally isolated from clinical samples, including skin and soft tissue infections, and may play a role in certain disease processes. Further research is needed to fully understand its potential clinical significance and ecological function within the human microbiome.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Corynebacterium senegalense
